habitat_description:
Populations of this species are found from north and central California then south along the coast and the western slope of the Sierra Nevada; trough southwestern California to northwestern Baja California. Disjunct populations occur near La Paz in southern Baja California (Grismer 2002; Grismer and Mahrdt 1996; Jennings 1983; Stebbins 2003). The elevational range extends from near sea level to approximately 2250 meters (Stebbins 2003).

The habitat includes riparian zones, grassland, shrubland, chaparral, savanna, and hardwood and mixed woodland. More specifically, this species can be found in chaparral foothills, rocky canyons and watercourses, oases in arid regions, shrublands with grassy patches, and mixed deciduous and pine woodlands in semidesert and mountainous areas (Grismer 2002; Stebbins 2003).

This species burrows in or using soil, decaying logs, and ground litter. It usually retreats underground or under cover during prolonged periods of inactivity. Eggs are laid in abandoned rodent burrows, other protected sites, or possibly even under imbedded objects (Natureserve.org).

SW	-Uses soil, fallen logs, and leaf litter as cover. It occurs in areas vegetated by pines, shrubs, and grasses.
